feat.name: Firearms Expert
entries: Thanks to extensive practice with firearms, you gain the following benefits:

items: You ignore the loading quality of firearms with which you are proficient.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls with firearms. This counts for weapons with the Scoped Feature too

When you use the Attack action and attack with a one-handed weapon shooting pistol bullets, you can use a bonus action to attack with a different firearm that shoots pistol bullets that you are holding.

entries: This feat enhances your proficiency with firearms, allowing for quicker reloads, improved accuracy in close combat, and the ability to make rapid successive attacks with pistols.

feat.name: Toughened
entries: You have honed your endurance and resilience to a higher degree, becoming even more formidable in combat.

items: Increase your maximum hit points by rolling a toughened die, which is a d4, and adding the result to your hit point total.
Each time you gain a level, roll the toughened die and add the result to your hit point total.

entries: This feat enhances the character's durability over time, granting them additional hit points with each level gained. It builds upon the foundation laid by the Tough feat, further solidifying the character's resilience in the face of adversity.

feat.name: Magical Insight
entries: Your magical ability have granted you an insight into battle.

items: You can give yourself a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your spellcasting modifier.

feat.name: Talented Preparer
entries: Whether through keen insight, natural charm, or profound intellect, you have unlocked the ability to prepare a greater array of spells.

items: The number of spells you can prepare each day increases by your proficiency bonus.

item.name: Flintlock Pistol
entries: A simple, single-shot firearm featuring a flintlock mechanism. It's the most common firearm found across Lumeeria, favored for its affordability and reliability.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Pistol Bullets(1 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Revolver
entries: A multi-shot firearm equipped with a revolving cylinder. It offers rapid firing and increased ammunition capacity compared to flintlock pistols.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Pistol Bullets(1 sp)

entries.name: Loading 6
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Musket
entries: A multi-shot firearm equipped with a revolving cylinder. It offers rapid firing and increased ammunition capacity compared to flintlock pistols.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Musket Rounds (2 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Rifle
entries: A specialized firearm with a rifled barrel for improved accuracy. Rifles are prized for their long-range capabilities and precision.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Rifle bullets (3 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Blunderbuss
entries: A firearm with a short barrel and a flared muzzle, firing a spread of shot or pellets. Blunderbusses excel at close-range combat and crowd control.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Blunderbuss Bullets (1 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Shotgun
entries: A close-range firearm with a wide spread, effective for hunting and close-quarters combat. Shotguns deliver devastating damage at short distances.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Shotgun Shells (2 sp)

entries.name: Loading 2
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Carbine
entries: A shorter, lighter version of the rifle, favored for its portability and versatility in close to medium-range combat situations.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Carbine Rounds (4 sp)

entries.name: Loading 8
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Derringer
entries: A compact, concealable pistol favored by nobles and individuals seeking discreet personal protection. Derringers are known for their small size and reliability.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Pistol Bullets (4 sp)

entries.name: Loading 2
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Sniper Rifle
entries: A precision firearm equipped with an arcane telescopic sight for long-range engagements. Sniper rifles are rare and highly sought after for their unmatched accuracy.

entries.name: Scoped
entries: When your within 20ft of your target, you have disadvantage on hitting them.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Sniper Rounds (10 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

item.name: Musket
entries: A multi-shot firearm equipped with a revolving cylinder. It offers rapid firing and increased ammunition capacity compared to flintlock pistols.

entries.name: Ammunition Type
entries: Musket Rounds (2 sp)

entries.name: Loading 1
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion
entries: There are now 10 points of exhaustion with each point from 1 to 9 give a -1 equal to the level of exhaustion one has. If a character reaches 10 points of exhaustion, they die immediately.
A characters speed is halved when they have 5 or more exhaustion points
This affects all your d20 rolls except death saves, meaning all your attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.
If you have a spell save DC, that is also lowered equal to your exhaustion points.

entries.name: Skipping Sleep
entries: Skipping sleep for 24 hours prompts one to make a D20 roll.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Falling
entries: Falling from a great height is a significant risk for adventurers and their foes. At the end of the fall, you take {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet you fell. There is no maximum height. You also land prone, unless you somehow avoid taking damage from the fall, such as with a special ability or the {@spell Feather Fall|phb} spell.

When you fall from a great height, you instantly descend up to 500 feet. If you're still falling on your next turn, you descend up to 500 feet at the end of that turn. This process continues until the fall ends, either because you hit the ground or the fall is otherwise halted.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Mastery Feature
entries: Mastery is a new feature that can only be granted through supernatural means.
Mastery acts like another layer of Proficiency, being above Expertise in the sense that it tripples a character's Proficiency Bonus to chosen skill.
A character can only have 1 Mastery Skill at any time.
Mastery gained through an item, should make the item Very Rare.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Inspiration
entries: Inspirations can stack up to the character's Proficiency Bonus.
If you are granted inspiration while at max, the inspiration is lost.
Inspirations can be given around the table, though certain situations do not allow for this, such as a character being temporarily against the party.

Inspirations work as a reroll of all the dice, including any dice gained from outside sources (Such as Guidance or Bless). If you have advantage on the initial roll and you choose to use inspiration, you roll with advantage again.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Attunement
entries: Attunement is very important in Dungeons And Dragons, as it limits the amount of magic items a player can possess if the items. The amount of attuned items a player can have at any time is changed from the standard 3 items, now being equal to a character's Proficiency Bonus instead.
The time it takes to attune with a item is changed to an action, though some items can have different attunement times. When you unattune from an item, you lose all abilities and benefits it gives.

variantrule.name: Lumeeria variant: Magic Scrolls
entries: If magic is put into a scroll, then anyone, even people not attuned to the Arcane Realm, can make use of the magic within. However, this only counts for weaker spells, being on the level of cantrips, 1st-, or 2nd level.

Magic scrolls and other magical elements are usable to martials and commoners, even if the user does not have proficiency in the arcana skill. To use a scroll, one has to tear the scroll in half to release the magic. This destroys the scroll in the process.

Any scroll of 3rd level and higher require an Arcana check to be successfully used. If the Arcana check fails, the scroll burns up without activating. If one has proficiency in arcana they have advantage on their arcana checks for using spell scrolls.

default: (a) a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} or (b) two {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@item light crossbow|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) an {@item handaxe|phb|two handaxes}
(a) {@item studded leather armor|phb} and {@item scale mail|phb}

classFeature.name: Fightning Style
entries: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take the same Fighting Style option more than once, even if you get to choose again.

entries.name: Archery
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

entries.name: Blind Fighting
entries: You have {@sense blindsight} with a range of 10 feet. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind total cover, even if you're {@condition blinded} or in darkness. Moreover, you can see an {@condition invisible} creature within that range, unless the creature successfully hides from you.

entries.name: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Great Weapon Fightning
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2. The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.

entries.name: Interception
entries: When a creature you can see hits a target, other than you, within 5 feet of you with an attack, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage the target takes by {@dice 1d10} + your proficiency bonus (to a minimum of 0 damage). You must be wielding a {@item shield} or a {@filter simple or martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon;martial weapon} to use this reaction.

entries.name: Protection
entries: When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll. You must be wielding a shield.

entries.name: Superior Technique
entries: You learn one {@filter maneuver|optionalfeatures|source=|category=|type=maneuver, battle master} of your choice from among those available to the {@subclassFeature Battle Master|Fighter||Battle Master||3} archetype. If a maneuver you use requires your target to make a saving throw to resist the maneuver's effects, the saving throw DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice).

You gain one superiority die, which is a {@dice d6} (this die is added to any superiority dice you have from another source). This die is used to fuel your maneuvers. A superiority die is expended when you use it. You regain your expended superiority dice when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Thrown Weapon Fighting
entries: You can draw a weapon that has the thrown property as part of the attack you make with the weapon.
In addition, when you hit with a ranged attack using a thrown weapon, you gain a +2 bonus to the damage roll.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

entries.name: Unarmed Fighting
entries: Your unarmed strikes can deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Strength modifier on a hit. If you aren't wielding any weapons or a {@item shield} when you make the attack roll, the {@dice d6} becomes a {@dice d8}.
At the start of each of your turns, you can deal {@dice d4} bludgeoning damage to one creature {@condition grappled} by you.

classFeature.name: Soul Power
entries: At 1st level, you gain access to your Soulburn Die, representing the fragments of your soul that you're willing to sacrifice for power. Your Soulburn Die starts as a {@dice d6} and increases as you gain levels in this class. Refer to the Soulburn Die coulumn of the Soulburner table

The Soulburner can utilize the Soulburn Die in various features. When rolling a Soulburn Die, the Soulburner takes damage equal to the result rolled as necrotic damage. This necrotic damage cannot be diminished or mitigated in any way. This damage goes through temporary hit points.

After each feature that allows you to roll a soulburn die. You can feel your future life being burned away, as you sacrifice your life expectancy for power. Sometimes it may be hours, days, weeks. While in other cases… Years.
Some of your Soulburner features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Mental Stat
entries: As a Soulburner you get to choose your own mental stat. Your options are the following: Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma. This stat will be used as your DC modifier, and as modifier for other relavant abilties

classFeature.name: Soul Succession
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain access to your Soul Succession ability. When you make a saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll your Soulburn Die and add the rolled amount to the saving throw result. However, you also suffer necrotic damage equal to the result rolled on your Soulburn Die.

You can use this feature once between long rests starting at 1st level. The number of uses increases to twice between long rests starting at 5th level, and to three times between long rests starting at 11th level.

classFeature.name: Soul Infusion
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your manipulation over your soul's energy allows you to imbue your weapons with elemental power.
As a Bonus Action, you can infuse your held weapon with one of three elements: Fire, Cold, or Lightning. Roll a Soulburn die and take the damage rolled.
Depending on your choice of element, your weapon is infused with said element for the next minute, dealing additional damage equal to one roll of your Soulburn die.

classFeature.name: Soul Path
entries: At 3rd level, as you delve deeper into the mysteries of soul manipulation, you choose a Soul Path that shapes the direction of your soulburner abilities. Your chosen path grants you additional features at 3rd, 7th, 10th, 15th, and 20th levels. There are four paths available: {@subclassFeature Path of the Soulstealer|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|3|ToL|Soulstealer}, {@subclassFeature Path of the Soulkeeper|Soulburner|ToL|Soulkeeper|ToL|3|ToL|Soulkeeper}, {@subclassFeature Path of Greater Soulburning|Soulburner|ToL|Greater Soulburner|ToL|3|ToL|Greater Soulburner} and, {@subclassFeature Path of the Dragonsoul|Soulburner|ToL|Dragonsoul|ToL|3|ToL|Dragonsoul}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Resilient Soul
entries: At 6th level, your soul grows resilient.

Your hit point maximum increases by 6, and it increases by an additional 1 point each time you gain a level in this class. You gain advantage against the {@condition poisoned} condition and become resistant to poison damage. Additionally during a long rest, you can now recover from two points of {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion} instead of one.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Soul Flay
entries: At 9th level, You learn to tear at the very essence of your enemies' souls, leaving them weakened and vulnerable.
When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can choose to roll your Soulburn Die to inflict a Soul Flay effect.

To use this ability, you willingly take necrotic damage equal to the result rolled on your Soulburn Die. Then, the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your Soul Power DC. On a failed save, it suffers disadvantage on attack rolls and the next saving throw it makes until the end of your next turn.
You can use this feature Twice. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use this feature again.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

classFeature.name: Soul Succession Enhancement
entries: At 11th level, your control over soul manipulation expands further, allowing you to extend the benefits of {@classFeature Soul Succession|Soulburner|ToL|1} to your allies in dire situations.
You can now use your {@classFeature Soul Succession|Soulburner|ToL|1} ability to aid allies within 30 feet of you as a reaction when they make a saving throw. The mechanics remain the same as before

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Soul Percision
entries: At 13th level, your control over soul manipulation allows you to augment your strikes  ensuring their accuracy at the expense of your own vitality.

When you make an attack roll and it is about to miss, you can choose to roll a Soulburn Die and add the amount rolled to your attack roll. However, using this ability inflicts necrotic damage upon yourself equal to the result rolled on the Soulburn Die.

If the added value from the Soulburn Die still does not result in a successful hit, you can choose to roll an additional Soulburn Die and repeat the process. You can continue to roll additional Soulburn Dice in this manner until you either hit your target or choose not to roll further.

You can use this feature equal to your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} modifier. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

classFeature.name: Soul Mastery
entries: At 14th level, your mastery over soul manipulation reaches new heights, granting you unprecedented control over your {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} ability. You gain the following benefits:

items: {@bold Extended Duration:} When you activate your {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} feature, the duration is now extended to 30 minutes.

{@bold Multiple Infusions:} You can now maintain three different elemental infusions simultaneously. This means you can choose three different enhancements from the {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} options and have all three active at the same time. However, you must still suffer the necrotic damage for each infusion activated. There can still only be one infusion active on a weapon at a time.

{@bold Allied Infusion:} You can now extend the benefits of your Soul Infusion to allies. As a bonus action, you can infuse an allies weapon that is within 30 feet of you. Like with your own infusions, you must still suffer the necrotic damage for each ally's weapon you infuse.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Unstable Surge
entries: At 17th level, you can channel the raw, unstable power of your soul into a devastating melee attack.

As a bonus action, you unleash Unstable Surge. The next time you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, it deals an extra {@dice 6d12} + Your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} (Minimum of +1) necrotic damage.

However this comes at a price. Your accuracy wavers and for as long as the Unstable Surge is active, all your bonuses to your attack roll, including magical weapon bonuses, momentarily vanish. As well as you rolling at disadvantage.

After Unstable Surge has been used, roll a {@dice d6}. The result of the {@dice d6} determines how many long rest's you must take before using this feature again. Additionally you must roll 2 of your soulburn die. The result of these equal to the amount of years taken from your life expectancy. As you've burned away those years.

classFeature.name: Mental Mastery
entries: At 18th level, your mastery over soul manipulation extends to your mental fortitude. You gain proficiency in your saving throw of your chosen mental ability score associated with your Soul Power DC.
Additionally, you gain advantage against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@filter feat|feats}.

classFeature.name: Soul Path Mastery
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Chosen Soul Path.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Soulstealer
entries: With this path, you learn to harness the latent energy of your soul to drain the life force from your adversaries, replenishing your own vitality with their suffering.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Tether
entries: At 3rd level you learn how to harness the fading essence of fallen foes, using their essence to protect yourself. When death looms on the battlefield, the Soulstealer can seize upon the departing soul.

When a foe dies within 15 feet of you, you can use your reaction to extract a fragment of their departing soul. Gaining temporary hit points equal to your Soulburn die plus your constitution modifier (minimum of +1).

You can use this feature once starting at 3rd level. Twice at 7th level and three times at 10th level. At 15th level you can use the feature as many times as you want. You regain any expended uses of this when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Lifesteal
entries: At 7th level, your control over soul manipulation grants you the power to siphon the life force of your foes to sustain your own vitality. After each use you can feel the stolen life force adding to your life expectancy.

As a bonus action, you can activate your Lifesteal ability. When you make your next weapon attack against a creature, roll your Soulburn Die and add the result as necrotic damage to your damage roll. Additionally, the amount rolled is restored to you as hit points.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Soulrend
entries: By 10th level you learn to tear at the very essence of your foes, causing grievous wounds that are difficult to heal.

After hitting a creature with a weapon attack, you can choose to unleash a Soulrend. If you decide to do so, roll your Soulburn Die and take the rolled necrotic damage yourself. Afterward, the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your Soul Power DC.
On a failed save, the creature cannot regain hit points until the start of your next turn.
You can use Soulrend two times per day. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use Soulrend again.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Lifesteal
entries: At 10th level, your {@subclassFeature Lifesteal|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|7} ability undergoes a profound transformation.

When activating {@subclassFeature Lifesteal|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|7}, you now add you chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} modifier to the necrotic damage dealt by the ability (minimum of +1)

subclassFeature.name: Soul Drain
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to unleash a devastating aura known as Soul Drain.

As an action, you unleash a aura of dread within a 10-foot radius centered on you. Each creature, friend or foe alike, must make a Constitution saving throw against the Soulstealer's Soul Power DC, taking necrotic damage equal to your soulburn die on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
You heal for the total amount of necrotic damage dealt. If a creature dies from Soul Drain, then the amount healed is only the remaining hit points of the target.
The Aura of Soul Drain lasts for a duration of rounds equal to half your Proficiency bonus rounded down.
Once activated, you can repeatedly unleash waves of soul-draining power as a bonus action each subsequent round.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Lifesteal
entries: At 20th level, your {@subclassFeature Lifesteal|Soulburner|ToL|Soulstealer|ToL|7} ascends to its ultimate form, manifesting as a passive ability that triggers once a turn whenever you strike an enemy with your melee weapon using an Attack action.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Soulkeeper
entries: Those who tread the path of the Soulkeeper eventually master the art of unleashing potent spells fueled by their own life force, controlling arcane energies with the very essence of their being.

subclassFeature.name: Sacrifical Magic
entries: Soulkeepers draw upon their own life essence to fuel their arcane abilities, sacrificing their vitality to wield powerful spells.

At 3rd level, as a Soulkeeper, you unlock the arcane potential within your soul, enabling you to cast spells fueled by your own life force. You learn to manipulate magic from the very essence of your being, using your vitality as a catalyst to manipulate the energies within the arcane realm.

To cast a spell, you must roll soulburn dice equal to the spell's level and take that amount of necrotic damage. For example, casting a 1st-level spell requires rolling 1 soulburn die, while casting a 3rd-level spell requires rolling 3 soulburn dice.

entries.name: Spell Slots:
entries: The Soulkeeper does not use traditional spell slots to cast spells. Instead, they expend soulburn dice, sacrificing fragments of their own soul to manifest arcane effects. The number of soulburn dice required to cast a spell depends on the level of the spell being cast, as outlined in the Soulkeeper Class table.

entries.name: Spells Known:
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you know three 1st-level spells from the Soulkeeper spell list. Every other level, you learn an additional spell, expanding your magical repertoire. You can choose any spell from the Soulkeeper spell list with a level you can cast. This and the total number of spells you know is listed in the Spells Known and Spell level column of the Soulkeeper Class table. The Soulkeeper shares its spell list with Wizards.
In the arcane arts of the Soulkeeper, your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} serves as your conduit for casting spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability:
entries: When casting spells as a Soulkeeper, you utilize your chosen {@classFeature Mental Stat|Soulburner|ToL|1|Tol|mental stat} as your spellcasting ability. This stat governs the effectiveness of your spells and determines their saving throw DC and attack rolls.
The formular for your spell save DC and spell attack modifier are as follows:

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus:
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your soulkeeper spells.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Insight
entries: At 3rd level, you become proficient in two skills associated with your chosen mental stat as well as acquiring an arcane focus.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Predator
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to harvest spells from spellcasters, absorbing their magical knowledge into your own repertoire.
As an action, you can attempt to harvest a spell from a non-friendly spellcaster within 15 feet of you.

To do so, make an Arcana check with a DC equal to the practitioner's spell save DC. On a successful check, you can choose one leveled spell from a list of three options provided by the DM, and that spell becomes permanently known to you, these spells can even be ones that are 1 level above your current casting limit. The possible spells are spells that the targeted spellcaster has access to, and the spells can only be chosen if they are in the wizard spell list.

Failure comes at a cost. If you fail the Arcana check, you immediately suffer backlash, rolling soulburn dice equal to your proficiency and taking that amount of necrotic damage. Additionally, you are incapacitated until the end of your next turn.
Once you've attempted to harvest a spell from a practitioner, the target becomes immune to further attempts from your Spell Predator feature for one month.

Alternatively, you can attempt to harvest a spell from the corpse of a spellcaster. The same rules apply, but there is no backlash for failing the Arcana check. However, the attempt might still fail for various reasons, such as the age of the corpse or the weakness of the lingering soul. Once a corpse of a spellcaster has been harvested for a spell, it is permanently immune to any further attempts from your spell predator feature.

After Spell Predator has successfully harvested a spell. Roll a {@dice d4}. The result dictates how many long rests you need to finish before Spell predator can be used again. This only happens if the Spell Predator successfully harvested a spell. Failure does not put the feature on a cooldown.
After you have acquired a spell from Spell Predator. That spell's level goes into a Predator Count.
The maximum of spells that Spell Predator can acquire are equal to your {@bold level + your chosen mental stat}.
For Example, acquiring the 3rd level spell fireball, would add 3 to the overall count. The maximum in this example would be 10 (Soulkeeper level) + 4 (Mental stat) = 14

You can choose to permanently abandoned one of these spells acquired through Spell Predator. You can do this for one spell each time you finish a long rest. After a spell has been abandoned, the spell's level is removed from the Predator Count and the spell can never be acquired again.

subclassFeature.name: Orbs of Keeping
entries: At 7th level, your character undergoes a transformation, as soul orbs manifest themselves on your body. The cosmetic characteristics of this transformation are determined by you, making them a personalized and distinctive feature of your character. The only stipulation is that these orbs must be visible to you.

For example, you might envision the orbs growing out from your collarbone Starting as marrow from the bone, gradually pushing through the surface of your skin until they become fully formed orbs affixed to your body.
Each soul orb can be used to store a reaped soul inside them until the soul is consumed.

When consuming a soul orb, each orb is considered 1 charge. For each charge consumed as a bonus action, the spell level is equal. For example, by consuming 3 charges, the soulkeeper can cast fly without having to pay the cost in soulburn dice. Similarly, the soulkeeper could consume 3 charges to upcast chromatic orb to level 3.

As a bonus action, you can consume a soul within a soul orb. Consuming a soul will make the next spell that you cast be free from rolling soulburn dice, as the spell consumes the stored soul instead of you.
The number of orbs on your body is equal to {@bold double your proficiency bonus}.
Each soul orb can be used to store a reaped soul inside them until the soul is consumed.

subclassFeature.name: Reap Soul
entries: At 7th level, you gain the ability to reap souls from recent mortal deceased humanoid creatures and store them inside your orbs of Keeping.
After reducing a creature within 30 feet of you to 0 hit points, you can as a bonus action reap the soul from the creature. Reaping a soul stores the soul in one of your unoccupied Orbs of Keeping.
You need to finish a short/long rest before you can use this feature again
Creatures whose souls have been taken from them are unable to be revived by anything other than a Wish spell.

subclassFeature.name: Memories of the Soul
entries: At 10th level, you can gaze into the memories of a soul that is stored inside one of your soul orbs.

You can spend 1 minute concentrating on a specific soul that is within your possession. After 1 minute you gaze into the memories of the soul. What you see may differ, they can be fragments, whole memories or even places that the soul remembers.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: Soul Glyph
entries: At 10th level, you gain the ability to inscribe a magical glyph using the energy stored within your soul orbs.

By consuming 2 charges, you can cast the {@spell glyph of warding|phb} without the need for any material components, the glyph functions exactly as described in the {@spell glyph of warding|phb} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Spear
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to conjure a Soul Spear and potentially tether it to a target's soul, enabling you to draw upon their essence.

As an action, you consume 3 charges of soul orbs and you make a ranged spell attack against a creature within 80 feet of you. On a hit, the target takes 3 soulburn dice damage + your chosen mental stat modifier (minimum of +1)

Additionally on a hit the Soul Spear remains attached to the target and a small arcane tether goes from you to the spear. For the next spell that you cast, the tethered target will take the soulburn dice damage for casting the spell, instead of you. The tether remains for 1 minute or until a spell has been cast.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Keeper
entries: At 20th level, you unluck the full potential of your soulkeeper abilities. The cosmetic characteristics of your Ultimate Keeper form is entirely up to you.
As an Action you consume 6 charges of soul orbs and you magically transform into your Ultimate Keeper form.

items: In this form you gain 60 feet of flight

While in this form, once a turn, whenever you reduce a creature, that meets the conditions for {@subclassFeature Reap Soul|Soulburner|ToL|Soulkeeper|ToL|7}, to 0 hit points within 60 feet of you. The soul of that creature is automatically reaped and stored in your {@subclassFeature Orbs of Keeping|Soulburner|ToL|Soulkeeper|ToL|7}.
While in this form, if you have a minimum of 8 charges of soul orbs. You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects

While in this form, if you have a minimum of 4 charges of soul orbs. You are considered resistant to your soulburn dice damage. Taking half of all the necrotic damage you deal to yourself through Sacrificial magic.

entries: You remain in this form for 1 minute. It ends early if you are {@condition incapacitated|phb}, if you die, or if you dismiss it as a bonus action.
You need to finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Greater Soulburning
entries: For those who choose the path of the Greater Soulburner, the boundaries of their soul's power are pushed to their limits. They can unleash devastating attacks that exact a heavy toll on their own essence, sacrificing their soul for raw, destructive power.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Soul Infusion
entries: At 3rd level, your understanding of soul manipulation grants you access to an enhanced form of Soul Infusion, known as Greater Soul Infusion. This ability allows you to infuse your weapons with even greater elemental power.
When you activate Greater Soul Infusion, you can choose one of the following enhancements:

items: {@bold Soulfire Surge:} Your weapon crackles with intense flames as you channel the fiery essence of your soul into it. When you make a weapon attack with a weapon infused with Soulfire Surge, you add your Soulburn Die to the damage roll as fire damage. Additionally, any creature hit by your weapon attack must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Soul Power DC or catch fire, taking additional fire damage equal to your Soulburn Die at the start of each of its turns until it takes an action to extinguish the flames. Additionally Each time the target takes fire damage from catching on fire, they can redo the Dexterity saving throw.

{@bold Frostbound Edge:} Frost swirls around your weapon as you infuse it with bitter cold, chilling the very soul of your enemies. When you make a weapon attack with a weapon infused with Frostbound Edge, you add your Soulburn Die to the damage roll as cold damage. Additionally, any creature hit by your weapon attack must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your Soul Power DC or have its movement speed halved until the end of your next turn as it struggles to endure the numbing cold.

{@bold Stormforged Strike:} Arcs of crackling lightning envelop your weapon as you harness the raw power of lightning. When you make a weapon attack with a weapon infused with Stormforged Strike, you add your Soulburn Die to the damage roll as lightning damage. Additionally, any creature hit by your weapon attack must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Soul Power DC. On a failed save, the target takes an additional 1d6 lightning damage. If the target is within 5 feet of another creature, the lightning arcs to the closest ally. The closest ally must then make a Dexterity saving throw against the same DC. On a failed save, the ally takes 1d6 lightning damage.

entries: Each of these enhancements follows the same mechanics as the standard Soul Infusion ability, requiring you to suffer necrotic damage equal to your Soulburn Die when activating the infusion. The only difference is that each elemental version of Greater Soul Infusion comes with additional effects tailored to its elemental nature.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Control
entries: At 7th level, your control over soul infusion reaches new heights, granting you additional ways to empower your weapons with elemental energy.
These additional methods of empowerment can also be combined with the elemental enhancements introduced through Greater Soul Infusion at 3rd level but cannot be combined with each other.

items: {@bold Soul Empowerment:} You can choose to pour more of your soul into your soul infusion, enhancing its potency. When you activate your Soul Infusion feature, you can opt to double the dice rolled both for your Soulburn Die and the elemental damage infused in your weapon. For example, at level 7, you would normally roll 1d8 for both the Soulburn Die and the elemental damage; with Soul Empowerment, you instead roll 2d8 for each.

{@bold Alternative Infusion:} You have discovered alternative sources for infusing your weapons with elemental power. Instead of sacrificing a fragment of your own soul, you tap into external sources. When you activate your Soul Infusion feature, you can choose take no damage from your Soulburn Die, but your weapon still becomes infused with the chosen elemental damage. This allows you to wield formidable power without risking harm to your own soul.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Overload
entries: At 10th level, you can harness the full extent of your soul's power, albeit at great cost.

As a bonus action, you enter the state of Soul Overload. To activate this ability roll {@dice 1d4}, the result you rolled determines the price for overloading your soul. You must roll the amount of Soulburn Die, equal to the {@dice d4} result, and take necrotic damage equal to the result.
While in this state, your weapon attacks deal maximum damage, but you cannot crit.

However, at the end of you turn, you suffer {@dice 1d4} levels of {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion}. Afterwards you suffer a backlash in your hit point maximum equal to {@dice 2d4} times 10. This effect lingers until your {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion} from soul overload is gone.

This powerful state lasts for your entire turn, after which you immediately gain the {@variantrule Lumeeria variant: Exhaustion|ToL|exhaustion} levels determined by the rolls. Once you have used Soul Overload, you cannot use it again until you complete a long rest.
After each Soul overload. Roll your soulburn die. The result from the roll is taken as years from your life expectancy. As you've burned away those years.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Cleaver
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to unleash a devastating cleave attack with your weapon.

As an action, each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Soul Power DC, taking your weapon damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The weapon damage benefits from any potential infusions on the weapon

As a cost, if there are 1-3 enemies within the cone, you must roll 1 Soulburn Die and take necrotic damage equal to the result rolled. This cost increases to 2 Soulburn Dice if there are 4-6 enemies, and for 7 or more enemies, you must roll 3 Soulburn Dice.
You can use this feature three times. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Soul Overload
entries: At 20th level, your mastery over soul manipulation reaches its zenith. Your previous Soul Overload state is now split into two. One being the Improved Soul Overload State and the other the Ultimate Soul overload State.
When you activate the Ultimate Soul Overload feature, you now push your soul to its absolute limits, abandoning your very life for overwhelming strength.
Only one of these Soul Overload States can be used once per long rest.

items: As a bonus action, you enter the state of improved Soul overload. While in this state, your weapon attacks deal maximum damage, but you cannot crit. This state lasts until the end of your next turn.
As a bonus action, you enter the state of Ultimate Soul overload You gain the following benefits when you enter your Ultimate Soul Overload state.
You're weapon attacks deal maximum damage.
Your Ultimate Soul Overload state now lasts for 3 rounds.
You can now critical strike while in the Ultimate Soul Overload state, and your critical hit range is temporarily increased by one.
You gain resistance to all damage types except Necrotic, Force and Psychic damage while in the Ultimate Soul Overload State.

entries: The Ultimate Soul Overload state remains even if you were to become incapacitated or die.
After 3 rounds in the Ultimate Soul Overload state, your soul is completely depleted and you die.
Only a Wish spell can bring a Greater Soulburner back from this Death. As it was not the death itself, but the burning of every last bit of their soul that led to their demise.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Dragonsoul
entries: With this path, you forge a contract with a powerful dragon, slowly changing your soul forever.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Contract
entries: You have successfully established a contract with a dragon of significant power. This contract will forever change your soul. Slowly turning you more towards the draconic.
The type of dragon that you have made a contract with also indicated your damage type for future Dragonsoul features.
Additionally you can speak, read and write Draconic.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Defense
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, draconic features manifest themselves on your body. While you are wearing no armor, your armor class is equal to 10 + Dexterity modifier + (Chosen mental stat) modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Form
entries: At 3rd level you learn how to temporarily unleash your soul's draconic power.

The cosmetic characteristics of this transformation are determined by you, making them a personalized and distinctive feature of your character. The only stipulation is that this transformation still needs to resemble your original humanoid form.
As a bonus action, you can assume your dragon form for 1 minute.
While transformed, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your jaw becomes elongated and you grow sharp fangs. Bite becomes a natural weapon for you that deals 1d6 piercing damage on a hit. You can use either Strength or Dexterity. Bite damage grows to a d8 at level 7, and again to a d10 at level 10, and finally to a d12 at level 15.

You grow sharp and deadly claws. Claw becomes a natural weapon for you that deals 1d4 piercing damage on a hit. You can use either Strength or Dexterity. Claw can be used both as an Action or Bonus Action. Claw damage grows to a d6 at level 7, and again to a d8 at level 10, and finally to a d10 at level 15.

entries: Your natural weapons from your Dragon Form can be infused by your {@classFeature Soul Infusion|Soulburner|ToL|2} feature.
You can use this feature equal to your Proficiency Bonus. Once you have expended all uses, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Breath
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you can unleash the destructive draconic powers that have been accumulating in your soul.

As an action you can exhale a 30-foot cone of Draconic breath. The damage as well as Saving Throw type is related to your Draconic Contract. Each creature in the cone must make a saving throw against your Soul Power DC, taking (Proficiency Bonus x Soulburn Die) on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Afterward you also suffer the Draconic Breath damage rolled as necrotic damage.
The Draconic Breath Cone is increased to a 60-foot cone at level 15.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Growth
entries: At 7th level, whenever you transform into your Dragon Form, you now grow to the large size.
While in your Dragon Form, you have an extra 10ft of speed.
Any attacks you make from your natural weapons now count as magical.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: At 7th level, you become resistant to the chosen damage type in your draconic contract.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Wings
entries: At 10th level, your Dragon Form now sprout a pair of wings from your back, gaining a flying speed equal to your current speed.
You can't manifest your wings while wearing armor unless the armor is made to accommodate them, and clothing not made to accommodate your wings might be destroyed when you manifest them.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Draconic Growth
entries: At 10th level, your Dragon Form now lasts for 10 minutes. Your form grows, as it now also includes a tail being up to 10ft long.
You can use your tail as a natural weapon, dealing {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning  damage on a hit. You can use either Strength or Dexterity.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Attacks
entries: At 15th level, whenever you use the attack action while in your Dragon Form. You can unleash a barrage of natural weapon attacks. You make one with your bite, one with claw and one with your tail.
You can use this feature three times per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Presence
entries: Beginning at 15th level, your soul holds the presence of a true dragon.

As an action you can unleash a roar, each creature within 80 feet of you and aware of you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your Soul Power DC or become frightened for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
You can use this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Dragon Soul
entries: At 20th level, you have reached the pinnacle of your Dragon Form.
Now each time you enter your Dragon Form as a bonus action. You can choose to transform into an adult version of your Dragon Type, instead of the humanoid version of your Dragon Form.

items: You can now stay in this form for however long you want.
You gain a flying speed of 80ft, as well as a climbing speed of 40ft.
You grow to the size of huge.
You are immune to your related damage type.
Your Draconic Breath damage is increased to 12d12 and you now only take half of the rolled damage as necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Puppeteer Sorcerery
entries: {@italic Created By : Victor}

Puppeteer sorcerers, whispered to be Velena's children, wield the dark art of manipulation. Hailing from the elusive Black Rose organization, these enigmatic sorcerers instill fear across Lumeeria. Their mastery over behind-the-scenes control, akin to the rumored powers of The Black Rose, chills the hearts of those who possess valuable secrets. Feared for their ability to puppeteer destinies, Puppeteer sorcerers embody the unsettling legacy of Velena's shadowy offspring, leaving an indelible mark on the lands they tread.

subclassFeature.name: Puppeteer Spells
entries: You gain additional spells at the indicated levels, as shown below. They are considered sorcerer spells for you, and do not count towards the total number of spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Pull the Strings
entries: Your charming demeanor is enough to let you get a grip on anyone’s mind, letting your words cut through doubt like daggers. You gain proficiency in Persuasion, or expertise if you are already proficient in it. Additionally, you can give yourself advantage on a Persuasion check an amount of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus per long rest, utilizing basic manipulation to influence others.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Companion
entries: You can control the movements of smaller objects with ease, tricking those around you into believing they contain some sort of life. You can perform a Connection Ritual by spending 10 minutes concentrating on a Tiny object, holding it throughout the process. After the 10 minutes have passed, invisible strings connect your fingetips to the object, letting you manipulate it at a distance up to 60 feet, and if the object would have a way of seeing, it can act as if you had casted {@spell Find Familiar}. The object has an AC of 10 + your PB, and has 1 hit point and becomes unusable if it takes any damage. It is immune to psychic damage.
An object connected to you lasts until you perform the ritual again or if it is destroyed. While the object is connected to you, you can use it as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

subclassFeature.name: No One's Marionette
entries: You gain resistance to Psychic damage, as well as advantage on saves against being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}.

subclassFeature.name: Force The Hand
entries: Your ability to charm and control others has grown significantly, allowing you to temporarily change the flow of combat to your advantage. As an Action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to attempt to puppeteer a creature within 60 feet of you. If a creature has Legendary Actions, or similar abilities, they are automatically immune to this feature.

The target makes a Wisdom saving throw, becoming Bound to you on a failed save. While bound, you can use your bonus action to decide what action the Bound creature will take. If you try to command it to do something that would bring direct harm to itself (Jumping in a pit of spikes, leaping out of a window, etc.), the target immediately escapes the bind. A Bound creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of their turn.
When you reach 11th level in this class, you can have 2 creatures Bound at the same time. When you reach 16th level in this class, you can have 3 creatures Bound at the same time.

subclassFeature.name: What Is Dead May Never Die
entries: Over time, you have realized that fallen warriors are not entirely useless, as long as you know how to work with a dead body. Luckily for you, you do. When a small or medium humanoid creature within 60 feet of you falls to 0 HP, you can use your reaction to cause ethereal strings to hold it upright, gaining a temporary ally. You can use a Bonus action on each of your turns to control the creature, which has the statistics of a Skeleton with any and all appropriate changes. When using your reaction, you can also spend sorcery points to empower your hold over the deceased target, giving it an amount of Temporary Hit Points equal to 5 times the amount of sorcery points spent + half your level (Rounded up) in this class. You are considered to be concentrating on this.

subclassFeature.name: Unwilling Devotion
entries: When a creature is affected by an Enchantment spell you cast, or a subclass feature, you can attempt to change their memory, as with {@spell Modify Memory} cast at its base level.

subclassFeature.name: Sever the Strings
entries: When a creature is freed from either {@subclassFeature Force the Hand|Sorcerer||Puppeteer|ToL|6} or an Enchantment you have cast on them, you can use your reaction and spend sorcery points to deal psychic damage to the creature equal to your level + an amount of d6s equal the amount of sorcery points spent. You can only spend an amount of sorcery points on this feature equal to half your level in this class, per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Puppets
entries: At 18th level, you gain the ability to channel all of your manipulative energy into a physical manifestation of control. As an action, you spend 6 Sorcery Points and gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: You gain immunity to Psychic damage, as well as being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}.
At the start of every turn, you can choose whether or not a creature either Charmed or Bound to you takes psychic damage equal to your Charisma modifier + your Proficiency Bonus.
When you deal Psychic damage with a spell or class feature, you can add your Charisma Modifier to the damage roll.
Creatures have disadvantage on their save against {@subclassFeature Force the Hand|Sorcerer||Puppeteer|ToL|6}.

subclassFeature.name: Lumeerian Gunslinger
entries: {@italic Inspired from Matthew Mercer's Gunslingers and altered to fit Lumeeria}

In the vast and varied world of Lumeeria, where magic and technology intertwine in unexpected ways, Gunslingers are a rare breed of warriors who have mastered the art of wielding firearms with deadly precision. Armed with their trusty pistols, rifles, or other exotic firearms, Gunslingers navigate the dangers of their world with a blend of steely resolve, quick reflexes, and a keen eye for their target.

subclassFeature.name: Firearm Proficiency
entries: Upon choosing this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools}.

Your proficiency with {@item Tinker's Tools} allows you to maintain, repair, and even create firearms. You can use your Tinker's Tools to craft ammunition, repair damaged firearms, or even design and construct new firearms, subject to your Dungeon Master's discretion. Your knowledge of firearms and their mechanisms grants your insight into their operation, giving you an edge in combat and ensuring your weapons remain in top condition.

subclassFeature.name: Firearms: Ammunition
entries: All firearms require specialized ammunition to function properly. Due to their rarity, finding ammunition for firearms can be challenging. However, with your proficiency in Tinker's Tools, you can craft your own ammunition at half the cost using gathered materials. Each type of firearm typically uses its own unique ammunition, which is often sold or crafted in batches to ensure compatibility with the weapon's design. As a Gunslinger, your ability to craft ammunition ensures that you're never caught unprepared when the bullets start flying.

subclassFeature.name: Firearms: Firearm Properties
entries: Firearms come in many different variations all from small flintlock pistols to large expensive sniper rifles.
Firearms in Lumeeria have replaced the optional ones presented in the {@table Adventuring Options; Firearms|DMG|Dungeon Master's Guide}.
Firearms can be found in the {@table Lumeerian Gunslinger: Firearms Table|ToL|Firearms Table}.

subclassFeature.name: Adept Marksman
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to perform powerful trick shots to disable or damage your opponent using your firearms.

entries.name: Trick Shots:
entries: Trick Shots. You learn four trick shots of your choice, which are detailed under {@subclassFeature Gunslinger: Trick Shots|Fighter||Lumeerian Gunslinger|ToL|3|ToL|Trick Shots} below. Many trick shots enhance an attack in some way. Each use of a trick shot must be declared before the attack roll is made.
You learn two additional trick shot of your choice at 7th, 10th, 15th and 18th level. Each time you learn a new trick shot, you can also replace one trick shot you know with a different one.

entries.name: Grit:
entries: You gain a number of grit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) + your proficiency bonus. You regain 2 expended grit point each time you roll a 20 on the d20 roll for an attack with a firearm. You regain all expended grit points after a short or long rest.

entries.name: Grit:
entries: Some of your trick shots require your targets to make a saving throw to resist the trick shot's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

entries.name: Bullying Shot:
entries: You can use the powerful blast and thundering sound of your firearm to shake the resolve of a creature. When making a Charisma (Intimidation) check, you can expend one grit point to gain advantage on the roll.

entries.name: Dazing Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to dizzy your opponent. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must make a Constitution saving throw or suffer disadvantage on attacks until the end of their next turn.

entries.name: Deadeye Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to gain advantage on the attack roll.

entries.name: Disarming Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to shoot an object from their hands. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or drop 1 held object of your choice and have that object be pushed 10 feet away from you.

entries.name: Forceful Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to trip them up and force them back. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet away from you.

entries.name: Piercing Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to fire through multiple opponents. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and you make an attack roll with disadvantage against every creature in a line directly behind the target within your first range increment.

entries.name: Winging Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to topple a moving target. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must make a Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Violent Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one or more grit points to enhance the volatility of the attack. If the attack hits, you can roll one additional weapon damage die per grit point spent when determining the damage.

entries.name: Blinding Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to blind your target with a well-aimed shot. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Concussive Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend three grit points to unleash a concussive blast with your shot. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Staggering Shot:
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to disrupt their balance and coordination. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or have its movement speed reduced to 0 until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Swift Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point to make a lightning-fast shot, allowing you to fire your firearm with incredible speed. When you use this shot, you can make one additional firearm attack as a bonus action on your turn.

entries.name: Smoke Bomb Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point to load your firearm with a specially prepared bullet that releases a cloud of obscuring smoke upon impact. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage, and a 10-foot radius sphere of thick smoke is created at the point of impact, {@table Screen; Obscured Areas|screendungeonkit|heavily obscured} the area for 1 minute. Smoke Bomb Ammunition is required to use this Trick shot and costs 20sp to make.

entries.name: Disrupting Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point to fire a disrupting shot that interferes with a creature's concentration. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage, and if it is concentrating on a spell, it must make a Constitution saving throw with disadvantage to maintain concentration from the damage of this attack.

entries.name: Harassing Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point, to fire a harassing shot that distracts and annoys your target. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Wisdom (Insight) check against your Trick Shot DC or it has disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures other than you before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Startling Shot:
entries: You can expend one grit point, to fire a shot designed to startle your opponent, causing them to lose focus momentarily. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage, and it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on its next saving throw until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Grit Guard:
entries: As a reaction to an ally being hit with a critical hit by an attacker within 30 feet, you can expend 2 grit points. You quickly toss a bag of black powder onto the attacker, attempting to distract them enough to disrupt their critical hit. The attacker and the affected ally must both be within 30 feet of you for this trick shot to take effect
The attacker must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or the critical hit is turned into a normal hit. Any effects triggered by a critical hit are canceled.

subclassFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: When you reach 7th level, you add your proficiency bonus to your initiative.
Furthermore, when you roll for initiative, you can expend up to a maximum of 3 grit points to boost your initiative score. For each grit point spent in this way, your initiative score increases by 2,

subclassFeature.name: Quick Thinking
entries: Upon reaching 10th level, your sharp wit and quick reflexes enable you to recalibrate your aim when your shots go awry in the heat of battle.

Once per round, when you miss with an attack roll, you can add your Intelligence modifier to the roll to potentially hit the target. If the modified roll is successful, you also add your Intelligence modifier to the damage dealt.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier, regaining expended uses after completing a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Quick Movement
entries: Starting at 15th level, you gain an additional 10 feet of movement, and you can use the {@action Disengage}, or {@action Dash} action as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Slinger's Aim
entries: When you reach 15th level, you add half of your proficiency bonus (rounded down) to attack rolls with firearms.

subclassFeature.name: Vicious Intent
entries: At 18th level, your firearm attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19-20, and you regain a grit point on a roll of 19 or 20 on a d20 attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Hemorrhaging Critical
entries: Upon reaching 18th level, whenever you score a critical hit on an attack with a firearm, the target additionally suffers half of the damage from the attack at the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Soulburner
entries: Soulburners are whispered about in hushed tones, their existence veiled in mystery and dread. They are feared not only for their formidable combat abilities but also for their controversial practice of soul manipulation. In a world where souls are the essence of life and balance, the Soulburner's unorthodox methods have drawn the ire of religious orders and individuals alike. The cosmic balance of Lumeeria hinges on the free flow of souls, and any disruption to this delicate equilibrium is met with swift and severe retribution. Despite this, or perhaps because of it, Soulburners continue to walk their perilous path, driven by an insatiable thirst for power and mastery over their own destiny.

As Soulburners harness the power of their own souls to fuel their abilities, they walk a precarious path between power and peril. Each act of soul manipulation exacts a toll on their physical and spiritual well-being, eroding away at their vitality and life expectancy. The exact toll this takes on their longevity remains unknown, but it is widely believed that few Soulburners live to old age. The lure of power may be irresistible, but the cost of wielding soul power is steep indeed, and only the most determined and resilient souls dare to embrace its dark embrace.

Soulburners have often been regarded with suspicion and fear, their abilities associated with darkness and corruption. Throughout history, there have been infamous individuals who have embraced the path of the Soulburner, wielding their power with ruthless efficiency. Among them, none are as notorious as Tionne Vestes, whose name is synonymous with destruction and chaos.

Tionne Vestes, delved deep into the forbidden arts of soul manipulation, becoming a feared Soulkeeper of unparalleled strength. Through unknown means, he transcended the boundaries of conventional Soulkeeper abilities, forsaking his martial prowess in favor of wielding soul power with unmatched potency.

His legacy is one of devastation, as he brought ruin to the once-beautiful Feylands, leaving a trail of destruction in his wake. Tales of his atrocities echo through the annals of history, serving as a grim reminder of the dangers posed by those who dare to harness the power of the soul. Despite his eventual downfall, Tionne Vestes remains a cautionary tale, a testament to the dark allure and perilous consequences of delving too greedily and too deeply into the forbidden arts of soul manipulation.

entries.name: Threatening Nature
entries: Furthermore, the very nature of the Soulburner often leads them into conflict with those who uphold the sanctity of souls. Most religious individuals, including clerics, paladins, priests, and even deities and devils, view Soulburners with suspicion and disdain. Simply by virtue of their existence, Soulburners are perceived as a threat to the cosmic order, prompting opposition from those who seek to maintain balance and purity in the realm. NPCs who discover the true nature of a Soulburner may become openly hostile or actively work against them and their goals, driven by fear or a sense of duty to preserve the natural order.

spell.name: Sapphire's Healing Rain
entries: Vitality bursts forth as rain cascades down in a 40-foot radius sphere, originating from a point of your choosing within range. You select up to six creatures of your choice within the sphere. Each of these creatures regains hit points equal to {@dice 8d6} + your spellcasting ability modifier.
Furthermore, any undead within the sphere must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, they suffer {@damage 4d6} radiant damage.

components.m: A crystal tear worth at least 100 Gold, consumed

spell.name: Evermoor's Photon Cannon
entries: You extend your hand, conjuring arcane energy in the form of brilliant photons. Make a ranged spell attack against a target within range. On a successful hit, the target is struck by a powerful beam of radiant energy, suffering {@damage 5d6} radiant damage. The intense force of the concentrated energy propels you backward 10 feet.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd. The radiant beam becomes even more potent with the infusion of additional arcane power.

spell.name: Adran's Disabling Eye
entries: You create a semi-translucent eye that hovers in a location of your choice within range. This eye temporarily disables all invisibility and illusion magic within 90 feet of it. Any {@condition invisible} creatures or illusions within range become visible and their illusionary nature is revealed while the eye is active. If an {@condition invisible} creature or illusion exits the 90-foot range of the eye, the invisibility or illusion effect returns.

m.text: A glass eye worth 50gp, not consumed

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the eye remains until dispelled.

spell.name: Sova's Undead Mount
entries: The pile of bones or corpse is engulfed in black flames; the smoke forming the body of the risen mount. You decide the mount's appearance though regardless the mount retains a look of undeath indicating its undead nature.
The risen mount is a Large creature that uses the statistics of the warhorse though it is an undead instead of a beast.
Your mount responds to verbal commands and can understand any language that you speak.

When your mount drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. You can also dismiss your mount at any time as an action, causing it to disappear in a plume of black smoke. In either case, casting this spell again heals your risen mount, restoring it to its hit point maximum.

components.m: The corpse of a large creature or one large pile of bones, which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Sand Stepping
entries: You and up to 5 willing creatures you choose within range become enchanted with the magic of the desert, gaining the ability to traverse sandy landscapes with unprecedented speed.
While under the effect of Sand Stepping, your movement speed increases to 60 feet while traversing sand.
If you are hit by an attack or offensive spell while the spell is active, its effect is immediately dispelled, and the enchantment is lost.
The spell provides protection against the abrasive forces of sandstorms. Sand Stepping ignores {@status concentration} checks caused by damage taken during such harsh weather conditions.
Dashing while under this spell has no effect.

components.m: Gold covered amber worth 50 Gold, Not Consumed

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the duration increases by 2 hours for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Naza's Divine Resurgence
entries: You beseech the divine energies, manifesting as radiant motes of light, to breathe life back into those who have fallen. When you cast this spell, up to three {@condition unconscious} creatures of your choice within range regain hit points equal to {@dice 3d4} + your spellcasting modifier. As the divine energy lifts them, they are also raised from a {@condition prone} position.

spell.name: Adran's Ice Spear
entries: You create three spears of ice and hurl them at targets within range. You can hurl them at one target or several.

Make a ranged spell attack for each spear. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d6} cold damage, and its speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. Speed reduction can stack with each hit.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you create on additional spear for each slot level above 2nd

spell.name: Nitto's Water Wave
entries: As you hold your hands with thumbs touching and fingers spread, a thin sheet of water shoots forth from your outstretched fingertips. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Strength saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 2d8} Cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The water pushed any creature that failed the save, back 5 feet.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Thunder Fist
entries: Make a melee spell attack against a target. On a hit, the thunderous energy is released, affecting the target and other creatures in a 15-foot cone originating from the target's position.

Each affected creature, including the target, must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 2d8} thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.

Additionally, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you by the spell's thunderous force, and a booming sound echoes audibly up to 300 feet.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 1st. The Target is additionally pushed back 5 more feet for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Azizas' Way of Fire
entries: You concentrate the elemental powers of fire. The next time you make a ranged weapon attack during the spell's duration, the weapon's ammunition, or the weapon itself if it's a thrown weapon, bursts into flame. Make the attack roll as normal. The target takes {@dice 2d10} extra fire damage on a hit. The piece of ammunition or weapon then returns to its normal form.

spell.name: Sova's Animate Limbs
entries: This spell summons a {@creature crawling claw} and a {@creature Stomping Foot|oow} to serve as temporary undead servants. Choose a pile of bones, a corpse, or a severed hand of a Medium or Small humanoid within range. Your spell imbues the target with a foul mimicry of life, creating a crawling hand and a stomping foot as undead creatures. The crawling hand and stomping foot remain for 1 minute. When this time expires, the creatures are destroyed.

On each of your turns, you can use a bonus action to mentally command either the crawling hand or the stomping foot if they are within 60 feet of you. You decide what action each creature will take and where it will move during its next turn, or you can issue a general command, such as to guard a particular area. If you issue no commands, the creatures only defend themselves against hostile creatures. Once given an order, each creature continues to follow it until its task is complete.

components.m: a drop of blood, a piece of flesh, and a pinch of bone dust

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, your undead servants remain indefinitely. There can be no more than 3 sets of Crawling Claw and Stomping Foot under your control.

spell.name: Spectral Blast
entries: A blast of spectral necrotic energy streaks toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d10} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d10}), 11th level ({@dice 3d10}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d10}).

spell.name: Fey Guest's Refuge
entries: Fey Guest's Refuge offers sanctuary to a select number of individuals, shielding them from the dangers posed by the Aetherwall that surrounds the Feylands. When cast, the spell envelops the caster and up to a number of willing creatures equal to their spellcasting ability modifier plus their proficiency bonus, granting them protection for 24 hours while within the Feylands.

Under the spell's influence, those affected are safeguarded against the perils of the Aetherwall, which threatens to unravel their memories and displace them in time. As long as they remain under the effect of this spell for the entirety of their stay in the Feylands, they are shielded from the adverse effects of the Aetherwall, ensuring their experiences remain unaltered and coherent.
